page.title: 04CUSTOMS AND FOLKLORE,SEAMILL
page.content: There is a true story about a small house in{Portencross}where there was a {MURDER. }A lady called the Beauty of Beith (a town approx. 15 miles from West Kilbride) was shot by a man who later shot himself. The motive is still unknown. The cottage is now used as a subject for painting. At{Easter we go up Law Hill to have a {religious service.}It is a joint church and congregational decision. During the service children roll their Easter eggs down the hill which symbolises the stone being rolled away on the first Easter. They also have a large cross at the hill-top. Down at the{Teachers Centre}in{Seamill there is a{ghost called the White {Lady.}Many people say they have seen her floating about the door of the centre. This has not been proven to be true.
